results.title: Making a wira
results.creator_credit: Ian Dunlop, John Martin-Jones, Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 14 of Series “People of the Australian western desert (A)”.
Djunjurai locates a suitable tree from which to make a small wooden digging dish or wira. He starts on the tree trunk by using the hand chopper he had made, but after a time changes to a metal axe. The raw material for the dish is brought back to camp where he shapes it with an adze.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ian Dunlop, John Martin-Jones, Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Making a stone axe
results.creator_credit: Frank L. Few and Australian Broadcasting Commission
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Alcheringa (A)”.
Shows how Australia’s Aborigine lived hundreds of years ago. Primitive methos of tool making require both skill and patience. By means of grinding stones, the stone axe is shaped to the desired form.

results.title: Making a Start in Oriental Brush Painting
results.brief_description: An introduction to this beautiful and absorbing art form. Kit Nicol, a talented watercolour artist shows the influence of her long interest in oriental art and culture and that the language of painting is universal. The various sections cover: starting to work, sitting position, brushstrokes, mastering of techniques, painting two subjects (roses and poppies) in full colour, and mounting and framing. Rated: G

results.title: Making a pack basket
results.creator_credit: Boy Scouts of America. Visual Education Service
results.brief_description: Pop Williams, an old-timer, demonstrates techniques for making a pack basket. He begins with the actual cutting down of an ash tree, stripping it out, and step by step, pounding out the weaving strips, weaving, attaching rims, handles and shoulder straps.

results.title: Making a music video on the cheap: from concept to completion
results.creator_credit: Greg Ferguson, AUSMUSIC and Conspiracy Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Basic music industry skills”.
Module 21.2. This program demonstrates how a broadcast quality music video can be made for around $1,000. Shows the operation of a video camera and techniques such as white balance. Australian band Pelican Jed, take the viewer through a step by step analysis of their latest music video, highlighting the roles played by each member of the production team including interviews with the producer and director. The emphasis is to take the viewer from the concept stage to completion; where an idea becomes a reality.

results.title: Making a Murderer
results.brief_description: Filmed over 10 years, this real-life thriller follows a DNA exoneree who, while exposing police corruption, becomes a suspect in a grisly new crime.

constellations_other.name: Reasonable doubt
constellations_other.description: Factual media has the power to reframe information and put forth new, persuasive arguments.  For the criminal justice system, where convictions are made based on arguments being convincing beyond a reasonable doubt, True Crime media has the ability to create doubt, right the wrongs of the justice system, and shed new light on closed cases.

results.title: Making a good impression (Captioned)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 11 of Series “Teenagers’ guide to the galaxy”.
Part of a series developed for young people aged 9-16 which deals with issues of communication skills, interpersonal skills, life skills and problem solving. “Making a good impression” discusses what is required to impress others, particularly when applying for a job. Includes hints and advice by teenagers and adults on appearance; manners and etiquette; respect for yourself and others; initiative; preparation; confidence. Features Colette Mann as Fay.

results.title: Making a decision in the family
results.creator_credit: Julia Murphy, Nicholas Balla and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Discussion film for adults on parental authority and teenagers. When a high-school girl declares her preference for going to a gathering of her own friends rather than to a family gathering, she runs headlong into her parent’s objections. It is their decision and not hers which is to abide. The result is a clash of wills. The question of what might have been a better approach is left with the film audience.
